;;T;<小>;所有战争小说的母亲;，套用萨达姆·侯赛因的一句话，一定是《战争与和平》。但是，就像 ;BBC; 的“荒岛光盘”为每位漂流者提供一本圣经和莎士比亚全集一样，我们也会把它放在你们的书架上;列夫·托尔斯泰的史诗;，假设他们还没有在其重压下下垂，然后继续。以下是七部最好的非托尔斯泰战争小说，按其所涉及的冲突的时间顺序排列。其中四部（《西线无战事》、《斯大林格勒》、《桂河大桥》和《战争的悲伤》）是用英语以外的语言写成的。我们选择的书籍主题涵盖世界各地的一系列战争——从佛兰德斯的战壕到越南的丛林。它们还表达了冲突的全部内容，从肉搏战的恐惧到永远无法愈合的情感创伤，这可能导致创伤后应激障碍（<小>;PTSD;）。 “战争是人类历史中至关重要、根深蒂固的一部分，”历史学家马格丽特·麦克米伦 (Magaret MacMillan) 写道。小说家和她的职业从业者对此有着同样的洞察力。

;;

;;西线一片寂静。 ;作者：埃里希·玛丽亚·雷马克;。 ;由阿瑟·韦斯利·惠恩翻译。 ;兰登书屋； 240页； 17 美元。优质的; £9.99;

;

;关于战争的坚定的虚构写作始于埃里希·玛丽亚·雷马克 1929 年的杰作。这是第一次有作家给出了对人们不择手段地互相残杀的原始、无情的描述。一位第一次世界大战老兵用德语写的《西线无战事》标志着维多利亚时代描写战争的撕扯传统的彻底终结。雷马克对西线德军战壕中的生活进行了描述，其中包括对肉搏战的生动描述，剥去了旧有的贵族和理想主义观念的残余，揭示了那场冲突的全部野蛮行径，以及非人性的行为。它对参战的年轻人产生了令人震惊的影响。它的第一批读者对这种细节毫无准备。该书出版后引起轰动，很快就销售了数十万册。即使经过无数次的电影改编，它仍然具有震撼力。 《一切安静》并不是一本明确的反战书，但它毫不留情的诚实让人很难把它当作其他任何东西来阅读。

;

;;再生。; 帕特·巴克著。 ;企鹅； 256 页； 17 美元。企鹅; £9.99;

;

;《再生》是三部曲的第一本书。它的续集是《门中之眼》和《幽灵之路》。所有这些书均出版于 20 世纪 90 年代，这十年间人们对第一次世界大战的恐怖重新产生了兴趣，因为人们知道参加那场冲突的最后一批退伍军人很快就会离开。这种纪念活动促成了塞巴斯蒂安·福克斯的宏伟的《鸟鸣》的巨大成功，这部小说讲述了英国矿工在索姆河德军战线下作业的故事。 《再生》将事实与虚构交织在一起，讲述了英国医生威廉·里弗斯 (William Rivers) 的故事，他开发了治疗他诊断为炮弹休克症的疗法。当时，大多数因极度情绪紧张症状而在战壕中瘫痪的士兵都被视为胆小鬼或疯子。里弗斯最著名的病人是诗人齐格弗里德·沙逊。这部感人至深、富有同情心的小说聚焦于他们的关系。

;

;;桂河大桥。皮埃尔·布尔著。由 Xan Fielding 翻译。 ;梅塔出版社； 174 页； 15.99 美元。优质的; £9.99;

;

;皮埃尔·布尔的小说于 1952 年首次以法语出版，应该被视为一部更好的电影的前奏五年后大卫·里恩执导的版本。它赢得了多项奥斯卡奖，并且仍然是有史以来最好的战争片。这本书和电影都不想传达这样的信息：第二次世界大战期间，缅暹铁路上盟军战俘的处境确实非常糟糕。一名幸存者表示：“没人需要告诉我们，这张照片充满了高调的鳕鱼冲击力。”布尔的主题不是战争的残酷，而是可能导致这种残酷的荣誉和责任准则。因此，他的故事主要是对人类性格的法医剖析，尤其是对军团的自豪感，以及即使在最可怕的环境下也能支撑战斗部队的军事纪律。小说的核心是两个同样勇敢但顽固的男人之间的意志之战：英国战俘指挥官尼科尔森中校和日军战俘营指挥官齐藤上校。两人都有过度发达的责任感。布尔展示了这如何导致荣耀和灾难。

;

;;斯大林格勒：一部小说。;作者：瓦西里·格罗斯曼。由罗伯特和伊丽莎白钱德勒翻译。 ;NYRB 经典； 1,088 页； 27.95 美元。哈维尔·塞克； 25 英镑;

;

;1941 年纳粹德国入侵苏联时，瓦西里·格罗斯曼签约为《红星》撰稿，红军报纸。他制作了有关前线苏联士兵的宣传报道。然而，作者出生于苏联乌克兰的一个犹太家庭，他并不是斯大林主义的走狗。他的作品表达了他对苏联人民面对法西斯侵略的勇气和坚韧的钦佩。格罗斯曼在两本关于 1942 年至 1943 年间发生的斯大林格勒战役的小说中回归了这个主题。第一本于 20 世纪 50 年代出版，尽管是经过审查的，书名是《为了正义的事业》。苏联政权禁止了第二部《生命与命运》，部分原因是它将斯大林主义与国家社会主义进行了比较。它被走私到西方并于 20 世纪 80 年代在那里出版。第一部小说的新英文译本是;2019 年出版;。它恢复了作者原来的标题“斯大林格勒”和未发表的部分。它现在被公认为是一部关于“伟大卫国战争”的经典作品，有力地融合了民事和军事观点。

;

;;《五号屠宰场》。;作者：Kurt冯内古特。 ;拨打新闻贸易； 288页； 18 美元。优质的; 9.99 英镑;

;

;几十年来;库尔特·冯内古特;苦苦挣扎，但讽刺的是，他未能写出他所说的“著名的德累斯顿书”。 1944 年突出部战役中，他在萨克森州首府的 1945 年 2 月的燃烧弹爆炸中被德国人俘虏。冯内古特在地下屠宰场聆听着炸弹如雨点般落下的声音。当然，他回忆道，描述这次经历应该是“容易”的，“因为我所要做的就是报告我所看到的”。但这句话却缓缓传来。冯内古特如何描述一座被“大火”吞噬的城市？最终，他的解决方案是用令人眼花缭乱的时空之字形结构取代正常的叙事结构。 《五号屠宰场》的主人公比利·皮尔格里姆以谨慎而偶然的方式揭示了德累斯顿的悲剧。小说于 1969 年问世后，他的讲述受到了后来被称为<小>;创伤后应激障碍;的心理错位的影响。《五号屠宰场》出版于越南战争期间，抓住了当时的反战情绪每年销量超过 100,000 份。

;

;;战争的悲伤。;作者：Bao Ninh。弗兰克·帕尔莫斯 (Frank Palmos) 翻译。;克诺夫； 240页； 18 美元。优质的; £9.99;

;

;这本引人入胜的小说作者是越南所谓的美国战争老兵，书中的鬼魂比活人更多。保宁是一名男子的笔名，他是光荣第 27 青年旅 500 名成员中的 10 名幸存者之一。他的主人公基恩同样是北越军队的幸存者。 1976 年，美国支持的南方政府垮台后，他的战争重新开始，当时他被送回以前的战场去打捞尸体。当他在当前的现实和过去的恐怖之间穿梭时，倒下的战友在“尖叫灵魂的丛林”中困扰着他，只有在他最遥远、梦幻般的战前青春和爱情记忆中才能找到安慰。与冯内古特的小说一样，《战争的悲伤》抛弃了传统的叙事方式，认为它们在地狱面前毫无用处。鲍宁及时创造了自己的变化模式，避免了感伤和刻板印象，描述了战斗对人类精神的影响及其后果。

;

;;一半黄太阳. ;作者：Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie。;克诺普夫； 435 页； 24.95 美元。第四阶层； £18.99;

;

;发表于 2006 年，;Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie; 的第二部小说发生在 20 世纪 60 年代末尼日利亚内战期间。主要由伊博人组成的反叛且盛产石油的比夫拉共和国于 1967 年脱离该国，引发了一场造成数十万平民死亡的冲突。当尼日利亚军队于 1970 年重新占领该领土时，这场战争就结束了。在《半个黄日》中，出生于 1977 年的阿迪奇女士试图对战争的可怕后果进行清算。 （标题指的是分离领土旗帜的中心图像。）与此列表中的其他一些书籍不同，阿迪奇女士的小说没有描写战斗。相反，她担心的是相互竞争的忠诚——对国家、对种族群体和对理想的忠诚——如何分裂和粉碎爱人、家人和朋友。阿迪奇女士还通过英国作家理查德的角色展示了西方媒体如何扭曲或忽视非洲的冲突。

;;W;;HILE 应用;到 ;耶鲁大学;（如图）2014年，Rob Henderson访问纽第一次来避风港。他和一个朋友的朋友住在一起，他的猫名叫“Learned Claw”（一种晦涩、自命不凡的暗示，暗指 20 世纪中叶一位名叫“Learned Hand”的美国法官）。亨德森先生没有收到推荐信。当他到达耶鲁时，更多的文化谜团等待着他。每个人都对他从未看过的电视节目《白宫风云》赞不绝口，而且“;汉密尔顿;”，一部他看不起的音乐剧。

;

;更多耶鲁学生来自顶层家庭1%的收入比来自底层的60%还要高。亨德森先生属于;不太富裕的少数群体之一。 ; 三岁时，他被从吸毒成瘾的母亲身边带走，并在八岁生日前与九个不同的寄养家庭住在一起。由于害怕、缺乏安全感和愤怒，他很快开始酗酒、吸毒并打架。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;17 岁时，当他的同龄人开始入狱时，他一时兴起报名参军。亨德森先生在结构化、纪律严明的系统中茁壮成长，并在<小>;美国;空军服役了七年。很明显，他非常聪明，因此《退伍军人权利法案》鼓励他申请大学。 （他最近刚刚完成了剑桥大学的博士学位。）

;

;《麻烦》讲述了他混乱的童年和在耶鲁大学的时光。以及这一切让他思考美国的分裂。根据他的经验，亨德森先生创造了“奢侈信仰”的概念，他将其描述为“一系列以极低的成本赋予上层阶级地位，同时给下层阶级带来成本的信仰”。

;

;过去，人们通过做一些劳动者不会做的“高尔夫或猎犬”之类的事情来展示自己的上层阶级身份。时间去做，或者通过他们的物质装备。但如今，每个人都更容易享受休闲时光和奢侈品，因此精英阶层越来越难以将自己与民众区分开来。他们的解决方案？ “富人已经将社会地位与商品脱钩，并将其重新与信仰联系在一起。”

;

;亨德森先生举了支持取消警察经费的例子。这个想法在;乔治·弗洛伊德的2020年发生的谋杀案;受到许多富人的拥护。然而，对于穷人来说，这是一项不受欢迎的政策——正是那些好心的大学生说他们试图帮助的人——并导致;凶杀率更高;。

;

;《麻烦》不仅仅是一本引人入胜的回忆录，它还分析了困扰美国大学的有争议的信仰体系。但它并不是一篇愤怒的文化战争长篇大论。亨德森先生没有发表政治立场声明。他写的很多内容都是常识。这是美国大部分中产阶级所相信的。

;
;
;
;
;< /div>;

;亨德森先生揭露了现在被视为正统观念的愚蠢之处，例如奢侈信仰阶层声称不幸福的方式与药物滥用或;肥胖;有关，例如，“主要源于它们引起的负面社会判断，而不是行为和选择本身”。富裕人士以“他们自己或自己的孩子永远不会接受的方式”来“验证和肯定边缘化和贫困儿童的行为、决定和态度”。一位同学认为;一夫一妻制;已经“过时了” ”但她承认自己是由两个父母抚养长大的，自己也打算实行一夫一妻制婚姻。

;

;现在的年轻人喜欢谈论“生活”经验”：个人因其身份、历史和观点而在特定主题上享有权威的观念。亨德森先生的背景使他有理由提出自己的担忧，但这并不意味着他的同僚正在关注。当他试图与耶鲁大学的同学交谈时，没有人愿意听。然而，读者将会全神贯注。 ;■;

;;James Bennet, our Lexington columnist, considers the difficulty of defining Trumpism;

;< p data-component="paragraph" class="css-1xm1z6f e1tt35bk0">;“It's not the Trump Party quite yet” was the headline on a Lexington column ;I wrote; back in January. Well, it is now. Donald Trump has locked up the nomination. He has installed loyalists, including a daughter-in-law, atop the Republican National Committee, and Republican politicians who once resisted him, having capitulated, are flaunting his endorsement. Nikki Haley, former governor of South Carolina, ran a good campaign, but primary voters mostly rejected her message, which was basically that of the politician who defined the party from the 1980s into the Trump era, Ronald Reagan.
;
;But I don't think voters can be certain just what this new Republican Party stands for, because, as Mr Trump demonstrated in the past few days, he remains such an opportunistic and transactional politician. He suggested he favoured “cutting” entitlements, then insisted he would do no such thing, and he reversed a position he held as president: while in office he issued an executive order to ban TikTok, a social-media app, if its Chinese parent company, ByteDance, did not sell the app's American operations. But this week he opposed a bipartisan bill in the House seeking the same outcome. ;The Economist; ;endorsed the bill; in this week's issue.
;
;Mr Trump explained that he wanted to combat a domestic adversary instead: “I don't want Facebook, which cheated in the last Election, doing better,” he wrote on his own social-media platform, Truth Social, with his odd, or maybe Germanic, capitalisation. “They are a true Enemy of the People!” Later, he suggested another political rationale: a lot of young people love TikTok. A third possibility is that the former president is courting donations from a billionaire investor in TikTok; Mr Trump has denied discussing the app with him. 
;
;Whatever his motive, or mix of motives, none speaks to protecting Americans' data or countering China. Yet Mr Trump said he still considers TikTok a national-security threat. It is this slipperiness about ends and means that makes Trumpism, unlike Reaganism, so hard to define apart from the man himself. Mr Trump calls himself pro-life, and he was able to appoint enough justices to overturn ;Roe v Wade;, but what will his position on abortion be in the end? I wonder if he knows. 
;
;Despite having served a term Mr Trump still offers less a set of principles than a mush of private and public aspirations and interests. That is a squishy new foundation for the grand old party. The fact that House Republicans overwhelmingly ignored Mr Trump's opposition and supported the ban suggests that, while they may bow to him as their political champion, they do not take him as seriously when it comes to policy. Let's hope some can show similar sense when it comes to aid for Ukraine and other matters.

;;E;;ARLY VOTING; in Mariupol began on March 10th, courtesy of armed election brigades who criss-crossed the city in search of participants. Sometimes, mobile ;ballot boxes; were unveiled to the sounds of rousing hits such as Sergei Voitenko's “My Russia” (Russia! Russia! My Russia! / Great country! Motherland!). Other times, guns did the talking. Those preferring to wait until the official start had a harder job. The locations of polling booths were not advertised ahead of the vote—a provision, officials explained, designed to ensure the safety of organisers. By the time polls closed on the evening of March 15th, the first of the three official ballot days, a stratospheric 69% of the region had already voted. This was all the more remarkable given the absence of accurate voting lists to calculate the number from.

;

;The vote in Mariupol could be written off as a farce, were it not for everything that went before it. The second day of voting came exactly two years after Russian planes dropped bombs on the city's main theatre while a large number of children were taking shelter inside, killing hundreds of them. Local authorities estimate that at least 22,000 civilians were killed in the city during weeks of bombardment. It may be considerably more. Only 120,000 of a pre-war population of 450,000 remain in Mariupol, plus a similar number of new migrants from Russia and central Asia.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Local sources, whose identities we are withholding for their protection, report that Mariupol has been unusually deserted over the days of the vote. The city still bears obvious war scars, they say. Central streets alternate between ruins and, where houses have been cleared, empty pits. Only collaborators who have proven their worth to the occupying Russian forces have been given homes in the few new-builds, hastily constructed for the cameras on the edge of the city. Access to the city is still tightly controlled, with checkpoints on the roads in and out. Anyone wanting to enter has to get permission at Moscow's Sheremetyevo airport, 1,000 km away.

;

;The Kremlin has been nonetheless keen for Mariupol to display loyalty 。 One of the very first acts of the occupying forces—even before the theatre was filled in with concrete in an attempt to contain the stench of rotting corpses—was to wheel in massive video screens showing Vladimir Putin. “They hadn't even opened the shops or the market, or the hospitals, but they had the big propaganda screens,” one local said. In the run-up to the presidential elections, there was a campaign to encourage locals to take up Russian passports. Its lack of success was perhaps most clearly shown in the decision in December 2023 to allow people to vote using their Ukrainian IDs, a rare example of a state allowing nationals of another one to take part in a presidential election. It is one of many avenues for voting fraud, suggests Mariupol's elected mayor Vadym Boychenko, now based in Ukrainian-controlled Dnipro.

;

;Solomiia Bobrovska, a member of Ukraine's parliamentary intelligence committee closely connected to resistance movements, says that Mariupol remains a partisan hotbed. “That's why they are so strict about the city. They don't trust locals with anything important.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The resistance effort can broadly be split between military and civilian wings. Partisan and diversionary activity in the former category is overseen by agencies like the ;SSO;, Ukraine's special forces, and HUR, its military intelligence agency. The ;SBU;, the domestic intelligence outift, leads on civilian resistance.

;

;Alongside this are other more independent activist groups, like Yellow Ribbon, which says it has 15,000 activists across Ukraine's occupied territories. The resistance is mostly low-level: printing anti-Putin posters and organising underground Ukrainian flag production. Its social media channel offers suggestions about how to avoid voting and share information about election organisers with prosecutors. “It's about giving people support, to show they are not alone,” says “Alex,” a co-founder of the movement. “Our aim is to irritate the hell out of the Kremlin.”

;

;Civil and military representatives are hesitant to discuss the extent of their networks, but it's clear that their work has become much more difficult since the early days of the war. Many agents have been compromised, hauled off to prison in the best case scenarios. Russia has dispatched tens of thousands of security officers to the occupied territories. Petro Andryushchenko, an adviser to the mayor of Mariupol, also in exile, admits the resistance was “losing too many people,” and suggests Ukraine should become more careful. He suggests encouraging locals to vote unless it was safe not to do so; a boycott was unlikely to change anything and could attract dangerous attention, he says. “The Mariupol resistance is different to everywhere else given our history and the level of control. At this stage we need to think about keeping people alive. They are our stake.”

;

;The Ukrainian government, perhaps surprisingly, has not produced a unified position on what its citizens should do: take part in the electoral farce to avoid reprisals, or ignore it. That is partly down to disagreement inside the corridors of power. But it is really because officials find it hard to admit that the liberation of Mariupol now looks remote. For Mr Boychenko, the exiled mayor, who has been criticised for his decision to leave his city in the early days of the war, the focus should be on helping the 200,000 or so survivors now scattered across Ukraine. “We are an evacuated city, a people in exile. But we haven't disappeared.” ;■;

;;C;;HUCK SCHUMER;, the majority leader of the ;US; Senate and America's highest-ranking Jewish official, is fond of noting that his surname derives from the Hebrew word ;shomer;, or guardian. Although his primary obligation is to America, he likes to say, he also feels a duty to live up to his name and act as a guardian of the people of ;Israel;. Mr Schumer made this familiar point during a speech on March 14th, but his remarks on the Senate floor about ;Binyamin Netanyahu; were anything but ordinary.

;

;“Prime Minister Netanyahu has lost his way by allowing his political survival to take precedence over the best interests of Israel,” Mr Schumer said during a 44-minute speech. “I believe a new election is the only way to allow for a healthy and open decision-making process about the future of Israel.”

;
;

;
;
;
;

;Presidents and secretaries of state have criticised Israel over the course of its 75-year relationship with the United States, typically on discrete issues for limited periods. Yet the de facto political leader of America's Jews calling for political change in Jerusalem is a watershed moment, even as Mr Schumer stressed that “Israel has the right to choose its own leaders, and we should let the chips fall where they may.” It reflects a crisis of confidence.

;

;Joe Biden, who often goes out of his way to avoid criticising American allies publicly, said the following day that Mr Schumer gave a “good speech”. (The president, however, fell short of fully endorsing it by only allowing that “many Americans” shared the majority leader's concerns.) Mr Schumer's Republican counterpart in the Senate, Mitch McConnell, called his remarks grotesque and hypocritical—the starkest example yet of the growing partisan gap on how to manage relations with the Jewish state.

;

;What effect could Mr Schumer's comments have on Israeli politics? Mr Netanyahu has not yet reacted, though his Likud party shot back in a statement that “Israel is not a banana republic.” Benny Gantz, a member of Mr Netanyahu's war cabinet but a rival minister likely to replace him if elections were held, said Mr Schumer's remarks were a mistake. In Washington earlier this month Mr Gantz met senior members of the Biden administration. A Gantz government would no doubt make the relationship easier, though unlike Mr Biden he is not keen on a two-state solution, so relations would still be far from simple.

;

;“Israelis of all political views are coexisting in the same bubble of trauma, insecurity, fear and worry. It makes them all incapable of hearing anybody or anything else,” says Martin Indyk of the Council on Foreign Relations, a think-tank, and a former ;US; ambassador to Israel. “They are largely oblivious to the suffering of the Palestinians and seemingly uncaring about the rift with the United States, Israel's only reliable friend in this crisis.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The greater immediate impact of Mr Schumer's remarks is likely to be on the debate over Israel in America. The Senate leader and the president are among the most pro-Israel Democrats in American history, but many on the party's left wing are deeply critical of the country's government. Mr Biden initially kept his criticism of how Israel has conducted this war private. Recently he has been openly critical while refusing to use his leverage, such as by withholding military support, or backing ;UN; resolutions condemning Israel.

;

;Mr Schumer's comments have given Mr Biden cover to take a tougher stance. But Aaron David Miller, of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, another think-tank (and a veteran negotiator of would-be Middle East peace deals), does not expect major changes to Mr Biden's “passive-aggressive” approach just yet. The only way for Mr Biden to resolve the political, moral and policy conundrums that Israel's assault on Gaza has produced, Mr Miller reckons, is for the images coming out of Gaza to change. Mr Biden may get tougher, “but I don't see it happening now, particularly given the fact that for the first time in weeks, there may be some openings on the ground” as Israel permits more humanitarian assistance and sends negotiators to Qatar.

;

;However, if an Israeli assault on Rafah, where some 1.4m Palestinian civilians are sheltering, produces massive casualties, Mr Biden's tone could become much more critical, much faster. “Whatever happens,” adds Mr Indyk, “pressure is now an overt part of the ;US;-Israel relationship.” ;■;
